This patch looks more like an variation of reserved host recovery workflow. It just treat the hosts in the segment as reserved hosts, and every time it would try to evacuate instances to one host in the segment.
I'm afraid it will lead to user misunderstanding and greater lag in recovery time. 
Let us listen to other's opinion.

In the Openstack, it's Nova which scheduler all the instances. The auto recovery mechanism for instance HA also rely on Nove scheduler, so the instances would evacuate across failover segments. I think the solution is to optimize Nove scheduler, such as add a new FailvoerSegmentFilter filter for instance evacuations, or we can input a scope of available compute nodes when calling Nova evacuate api.
Now there are for recovery mechanism, 'auto', 'reserved_host', 'auto_priority', 'rh_priority'. But this patch, it is an variation of reserved host recovery mechanism, which makes the four recovery mechanism more like one, and it would reduce the success rate of evacuation especially for 'auto_priority' and 'rh_priority' recovery mechanism.

I agree with you that the correct approach will be to enhance Nova scheduler for the functionality required rather than the retry node by node approach used in the patch. This patch is more of a workaround which has its cons as I mentioned earlier.
Looking at the API documentation, conceptually the recovery mechanism shall only work within the segment. And this is not the case with AUTO, so it will be great if this can be mentioned explicitly in the documentation.

neutron/privileged/agent/linux/ip_lib.py.message:
I know this is still a WIP patch.

Some comments:
1) I would add this decorator before the privsep one. As is now, the retry will be done inside the privsep context. That could take time and starve other privsep threads.

2) This "NetlinkDumpInterrupted" exception was added to "NetlinkMixin.nlm_request", that is the parent class of "NetlinkSocket".

"IPRoute" (most of our Pyroute2 commands use it) is:
  class IPRoute(RTNL_API, IPRSocket)
  --> class IPRSocket(IPRSocketMixin, NetlinkSocket)
  --> class NetlinkSocket(NetlinkMixin)

That means almost any command we use ("tc", "bridge", "neigh", "ip-link", "ip-addr", "ip-route", "ip-rule") uses "nlm_request" to send and receive a request from the "iproute" library.

1) ack
2) If I understand from [1] & [2] and from your comment (and the code in pyroute which you referenced), we have to add retry logic to all get_* / list_* methods? Like get_ip_addresses, list_ip_rules, list_ip_routes...

[1]: https://elixir.bootlin.com/linux/v3.2/source/include/linux/netlink.h#L53
[2]: https://elixir.bootlin.com/linux/v3.2/source/include/net/netlink.h#L649
Yeah, I think we'll need to add this retry to all those methods that could return NetlinkDumpInterrupted.
You will probably need to bump lower-constraint's requirements too as now lower-constraints job is failing due to missing that exception
sure, I changed it to 0.6.6 which introduced NLM_F_DUMP_INTR handling and NetlinkDumpInterrupted

  DnfStreams: [{'module':'container-tools', 'stream':'3.0', 'version':'8'}]

golang-dev/golang-github-checkpoint-rest.message: Any reason why the checksums fields such as sha256sum: are not provided here?  Even if our scriptware doesn't check them when the archive tag is used, it's still probably a good idea to capture the sha256sum anyway, at least for posterity and perhaps things will tighten up in the future.

The only reason why it is not added is that our scripts do not check them when using archive tag. I completely agree with that it's a good idea to have it. But IMO we should first have a prototype here https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/StarlingX/DebianBuildStructure that describes how to maintain a sha256sum when using archives, so the build scripts do not fail to parse the meta_data.yaml.
Shouldn't we use $STX_DIST here instead of hardcoding it?

Root disk image build failing with: Element 'rocky' not found

There are actually multiple issues here:

1) This patch uses overcloud_dib_build_host_images, but this is only supported in master. So it is ignored and Bifrost tries to build the VM image.
2) The DIB element is rocky-container rather than rocky.
3) Bifrost uses DIB master, but IIRC it doesn't support building rocky-container images?

So I am not sure we support building a Rocky disk image on Xena. Should we backport the overcloud-dib feature?
I think it needs a newer DIB. We probably missed this before due to disabling Ubuntu host image builds via ansible_os_family, which also skipped Rocky
I think we agreed to keep Rocky image builds out of scope for Xena & earlier. So we could put in a conditional.
Rocky job logs show that it is building centos-based IPA images and container base image. This is what we want, right? We're just testing that the build works on this different host OS?
Correct. Ubuntu also builds a CentOS IPA, and Rocky is not supported as a container OS currently.
Is it possible to add a test for this in neutron/tests/functional/pecan_wsgi/test_hooks.py ? Seems like something we'd want to verify.

Without the fix, our Kolla have startup issues because it is not executable:
   -rw-r-----. 1 root root 348 Jan 1 1970 kolla_extend_start

Should also mention the Toolbox Dockerfile is the only one missing the chmod on kolla_extend_start.


Thanks!
Well, these files are sourced, not executed, so the executable bit is irrelevant. I don't think we should make this one executable, we should rather drop the executable bit from the others. ;-)
Yes, that sounds sensible, but may be quite a bit of work. Let's just set 644 in here (and is not it the usual default? are you getting something else?).

You're correct, the file needs to be explicitly set readable by the "other" permission level (chmod o+r) or else it can't be sourced. So a change is still needed here, albeit without the executable bits.

For consistency, I can change the kolla_extend_start permissions to  644 across all the Dockerfiles (subject to testing, obviously). Sound ok? Thanks!
I wonder if this is the result of using a non-default umask?

It does appear to be umask related. We have private Kolla builds that are fine, and Jenkins builds with 640 permissions on this file.

Either way, it seems prudent to update the kolla-toolbox, just because it's the outlier (only Dockerfile without the explicit chmod).

I have surveyed/updated all the chmods to 644 for "extend" startup files and am currently testing. Happy to submit all, or just limit it to the toolbox :)

tests/unit/test_model_upgrade.py.message: Small nit. Might be worth indicating why this is: because small secrets continue to use the old system which uses fewer zk operations if I read correctly.

zuul/model.py.message: Just making sure I understand properly. The blob store is storing binary data as provided (possibly sharding it). This means we are storing the encrypted values here right?
Yeah, at this point, we don't decrypt anything until we get to the executor.

zuul/scheduler.py.message: I think this might race with new items enqueuing and using the same secrets since we've dropped the locks? We might need to do these deletions with the same lock context held as when we build the list to prevent that?

I think you're right.  I think we can correct this by doing the following:

1) Lock the blob in the delete method
2) Within the lock in the delete method, double check that it hasn't been used since our start time.

We don't delete the blob lock inside the delete method (it's side channel locking, so we don't have to worry about recursively deleting a thing we're locking), so that will create mutually exclusive critical sections with adding entries to the store and deleting them.

I think we should also get the tenant read lock to be consistent with our lock sequences in other places. When the tenant write lock is acquired we assume exclusive access to the tenant and all its pipelines.
Seems we are also not read locking the tenant in `_cleanupNodeRequests()`, so ignore my comment here.
Do we need to refresh the pipeline change list and summary here? It doesn't look like we are using that here.

zuul/zk/blob_store.py.message: Small nit: {key[0:2]} might make it slightly clearer we want the prefix slice of the hash name. I wasn't sure if we were indexing a dict or not initially. But this is minor if you go read the put() code it is super clear.

I guess blocking on the lock here before we return if the data was written by someone else ensures the write by someone else is complete before we report back that the key is present? The alternative to using a lock would be to just let everyone write and let zk sort out the order of operations. But if we do that then a read could happen after someone has deleted the content to rewrite it and before the rewrite is complete.

Yes -- it's sharded, so we want to make sure it's complete before we decide whether it's present or not -- otherwile we'll have corrupted data.  And we need to add locking to delete, at which point this will be mutually exclusive with that.

Since this is a content-addressible store, we shouldn't actually have anyone rewriting it (unless it's been deleted).
Do we want to retry this indefinitely? I'm little afraid of schedulers/executors hanging because of that.

Yes -- that is what we do with zkobjects, and this is replacing something handled by zkobject now.

It shouldn't hang indefinitely -- if we lose the session, it will abort.

I agree this should work because the flag is touched whenever we put the blob regardless of whether or not any data is written in the process. And we set ltime while holding the lock when we build the list of deletable blobs.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
To support signed repository, we need:
1) Construct a gpg key pair. Here I just make a temporary pair with password as "starlingx"
2) Insert the private key into aptly container to sign the repository with it;
3) Insert the public key into the apt-key rings of all needed containers, to access the signed repository.

This modification just add the the feature but not activate it. Once this is done, "deb_aptly_usage.py" of "root" layer need to be modified to activate it(Sign the repository with the new added key).

To support signed repository, we need:
1) Construct a gpg key pair. Here I just make a temporary pair with password as "starlingx"
2) Insert the private key into aptly container to sign the repository with it;
3) Insert the public key into the apt-key rings of all needed containers, to access the signed repository.

build-tools/stx/aptly_deb_usage.py.message: Why do we need the sleep here?

I double checked the aptly's source code, we have no chance to sync the operation but the operation itself is sync, So I just removed the "sleep", it is safe.

>That's the total time we expect to loose on this delete operation?
In normal case, there is no such file folder. If there is, no more than one folder, and no more than one package in it.

The "delete" operation above just tell aptly to make it and will return immedietly. Without such a "sleep", sometimes the next operation will cause "resource conflict" in aptly.
I common cases, aptly has no such "file folder", only in corner cases that the process bee interrupted after "files.upload" and before "ros.add_uploaded_file", there will be such a file folder contains one Debian package. Thus may be added into different repository. Here, one second is enough.

How many files are we deleting in this manner?  
That's the total time we expect to loose on this delete operation?
The method doesn't accept a list?
Sleep may work by chance, but I think a better solution should include some kind of synchronization with the service.
